message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and symptoms suggest that the most likely injury is a medial meniscus tear. The popping sound and locking sensation supports this diagnosis as well. External rotation is not typically associated with meniscus tears, and ACL or PCL injuries usually result from a twisting motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the pain is mostly at the medial aspect of the knee, and that external rotation elicits pain and locking sensation, suggest a medial meniscus tear. Anterior and posterior cruciate ligament injuries usually present with instability, while lateral meniscus injuries usually present with pain on the lateral aspect of the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the symptoms suggest a medial meniscus tear. The popping sound, locking sensation, and medial tenderness are all hallmarks of this injury. External rotation of the knee is not typically associated with meniscus tears but is more commonly associated with ligamentous injuries such as anterior cruciate ligament or lateral collateral ligament tears.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The popping sound, pain on the medial aspect, locking sensation, and tenderness suggest a medial meniscus tear, which can cause the knee to lock in a specific position. Anterior and posterior cruciate ligament injuries may cause instability, while lateral meniscus tears may cause pain on the lateral side.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the injury suggests a medial meniscus tear, which can cause sharp pain and a locking sensation in the knee. External rotation of the knee is more likely to cause pain with a medial meniscus tear. The anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments are less likely to be injured in this mechanism of injury. A lateral meniscus tear may cause pain on the lateral aspect of the knee, but is less likely in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a medial meniscus tear, which is commonly caused by a twisting or rotating force to the knee joint, often seen in sports injuries like soccer. The popping sound and sharp pain with locking sensation are also common symptoms of a meniscus tear. External rotation eliciting sharp pain further supports the diagnosis of a medial meniscus tear rather than ACL or PCL injury. Lateral meniscus tear can also cause similar symptoms, but medial meniscus tears are more common.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury, popping sound, and locking sensation suggest a medial meniscus tear. Lateral meniscus injury will result in pain on the lateral side of the knee. Anterior and posterior cruciate ligament injuries do not cause locking sensation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a medial meniscus tear, as there is tenderness mostly at the medial aspect of the knee and external rotation elicits sharp pain with a locking sensation. Anterior and posterior cruciate ligament injuries usually result in instability and giving way of the knee, while lateral meniscus tear would result in tenderness at the lateral aspect of the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the locking sensation suggest a medial meniscus tear. The popping sound and inability to stand or walk suggest a significant injury. External rotation causing pain is a classic sign of medial meniscus tear. Anterior and posterior cruciate ligament injuries usually present with a feeling of instability and giving way rather than locking. Lateral meniscus tears typically do not cause locking unless the tear is significant and involves the posterior horn.

We refer to a study published in the Journal of Orthopaedic Surgery and Research for help. The popping sound, severe pain, and locking sensation suggest a possible meniscus tear. The medial meniscus is more commonly injured than the lateral meniscus in sports-related injuries, especially in soccer. The physical examination finding of tenderness at the medial aspect of the knee supports this diagnosis. The anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments are less likely to be injured in this scenario.
